name: A/B Testing
definition: A quantitative method that compares two versions of a design by randomly showing each version to users and measuring which performs better on specific metrics. A/B testing provides statistical evidence for design decisions by measuring actual behavior.

name: Accessibility
definition: Inclusive design enabling users with disabilities to use digital interfaces equally.

name: Accessibility Audit
definition: A systematic evaluation of a product's compliance with accessibility standards (WCAG) and usability for people with disabilities. Accessibility audits use automated tools, manual testing, and assistive technology to identify barriers and ensure inclusive design.

name: Accessibility Documentation
definition: Guidelines ensuring WCAG compliance in design deliverables.

name: Accessibility Personas
definition: User archetypes with specific disabilities.

name: Accessibility Testing
definition: Screen reader keyboard WCAG compliance validation.

name: Accessibility Tree
definition: Browser DOM representation for assistive technology.

name: Accessible Color Pairing
definition: A method for systematically identifying and documenting color combinations that meet accessibility contrast requirements. Pairing involves testing foreground colors against multiple backgrounds to create a matrix of compliant combinations for text, icons, and interactive elements.

name: Acquisition Cost (CAC)
definition: Cost acquiring single paying customer.

name: Active State
definition: Visual indication during interaction (button pressed, link activating).

name: Affinity Diagramming
definition: A collaborative method for organizing large amounts of qualitative data by grouping related observations, ideas, or insights into clusters. Affinity diagramming synthesizes research findings into patterns and reveals relationships between data points.

name: Affordance
definition: Visual cues suggesting possible interactions (raised button, pointer cursor, icon meaning).

name: AI Design Assist
definition: Machine learning accelerates design workflow.

name: Alignment Principle
definition: Consistent positioning creates visual order.

name: Analogy Brainstorming
definition: Apply solutions from unrelated domains to current problem.

name: Animation Frame Budget
definition: Frame rendering performance target for smooth motion.

name: App Clip
definition: Lightweight iOS app experience no download.

name: App Gesture Back
definition: Edge swipe returns to previous screen.

name: App Icon Grid
definition: Home screen icon arrangement and spacing.

name: App State Restoration
definition: Previous session state reload on app relaunch.

name: App Store Screenshot
definition: Marketing visuals for app store product pages.

name: ARIA
definition: Accessible Rich Internet Applications - attributes for dynamic content.

name: ARIA Live Regions
definition: Announce dynamic content changes screen readers.

name: Artistic Fonts
definition: Highly stylized, decorative typefaces designed for visual impact and expression. Artistic fonts are used sparingly for headlines, branding, or special occasions to create distinctive visual statements.

name: Asset Sheet
definition: Organized collection of production-ready design files and specifications.

name: Assumption Mapping
definition: Risk-prioritize untested product hypotheses.

name: Async Design Review
definition: Asynchronous documented feedback system.

name: Atomic Design
definition: Methodology organizing UI components into five hierarchical levels: atoms, molecules, organisms, templates, and pages for scalable systems.

name: Atomic Design Workflow
definition: Atoms Molecules Organisms Templates Pages build order.

name: Backlog Refinement
definition: Prioritization grooming 1-2 weeks ahead.

name: Beta Testing
definition: Releasing a product or feature to a limited group of real users in production environment before full launch. Beta testing identifies issues, gathers feedback, and validates performance with actual usage patterns and data.

name: Bottom Navigation
definition: Fixed bottom bar with 4-5 primary destinations (common in mobile apps).

name: Bounce Rate
definition: Percentage single-page sessions without interaction.

name: Brainstorming
definition: A group creativity technique for generating a large number of ideas in a short time by encouraging free thinking and deferring judgment. Brainstorming leverages diverse perspectives to explore solution spaces broadly before evaluating ideas.

name: Brainwriting 6-3-5
definition: Six people write 3 ideas in 5 minutes then rotate papers.

name: Brand Guidelines
definition: Rules maintaining visual identity across touchpoints.

name: Breadcrumb Navigation
definition: Shows current location and path from home (Home > Category > Product).

name: Breadcrumb Trail
definition: Hierarchical path showing current location (Home > Category > Subcategory).

name: Browser Support Matrix
definition: Specific browsers and versions officially supported by website.

name: Build-Measure-Learn
definition: MVP feedback loop continuous product learning.

name: Business Dashboard
definition: Multi-chart display of key business metrics on single performance overview.

name: Card Sorting
definition: A research method where participants organize topics or content into categories that make sense to them. Card sorting reveals how users mentally model information and helps inform information architecture and navigation structure.

name: Cascade Layers
definition: Explicit CSS cascade control priority.

name: Chart Hover Tooltip
definition: Pop-up panel shows precise values and context on data point interaction.

name: Churn Rate
definition: Percentage users abandoning product over time period.

name: Cognitive Load
definition: Mental effort required to understand/use interface.

name: Cognitive Walkthrough
definition: An expert evaluation method that assesses how easy an interface is to learn by walking through tasks from a new user's perspective. Cognitive walkthrough focuses on learnability and whether users can understand what to do without training.

name: Cohort Retention Curve
definition: Retention patterns by user acquisition group.

name: Color Blindness Simulation
definition: A testing method that simulates how designs appear to users with different types of color vision deficiency. Common simulations include protanopia (red-blind), deuteranopia (green-blind), tritanopia (blue-blind), and achromatopsia (complete color blindness), helping identify problematic color dependencies.

name: Color Contrast Testing
definition: A method for verifying that color combinations meet accessibility standards for readability. Testing measures the luminance ratio between foreground and background colors against WCAG thresholds: 4.5:1 for normal text (AA), 3:1 for large text (AA), and 7:1 for enhanced contrast (AAA).

name: Color Extraction
definition: A method for deriving color palettes from existing visual sources such as photographs, brand materials, or artwork. Extraction identifies dominant, secondary, and accent colors from an image to create cohesive palettes grounded in real-world references.

name: Color Overlay Testing
definition: A method for verifying color readability and visual hierarchy when UI elements are layered with transparency or overlays. Testing ensures that text, icons, and interactive elements remain legible on semi-transparent backgrounds, modals, scrims, and overlapping surfaces.

name: Color Proportion Rule
definition: A color distribution guideline that suggests using a dominant color for 60% of the design, a secondary color for 30%, and an accent color for 10%. This ratio creates visual balance and hierarchy while preventing color overload.

name: Color Scale Generation
definition: A method for creating systematic tonal variations of a base color, typically producing a scale from light to dark (e.g., 50, 100, 200... 900). Color scales provide consistent options for different UI states, backgrounds, and text while maintaining color harmony.

name: Color Schemes
definition: A structured method for selecting harmonious color combinations based on their relationships on the color wheel. Common schemes include complementary (opposite colors), analogous (adjacent colors), triadic (three equidistant colors), and split-complementary (one color plus two adjacent to its complement).

name: Color Spaces
definition: A color space is a mathematical model that defines how colors are represented as numerical values. Different color spaces serve different purposes: RGB for screens, CMYK for print, HSL/HSB for intuitive adjustments, and LAB/LCH for perceptually uniform color work.

name: Color Tokens
definition: A systematic approach to organizing colors in design systems using hierarchical abstraction levels: primitive tokens (raw color values), semantic tokens (purpose-based names like "text-primary"), and component tokens (context-specific like "button-background"). This structure enables consistent theming and maintainability.

name: Column Chart
definition: Vertical bars compare category values side-by-side for easy magnitude comparison.

name: Comparison Testing
definition: A research method where participants evaluate multiple design alternatives side-by-side to determine preferences and relative strengths. Comparison testing helps teams make decisions between competing approaches by understanding user reasoning.

name: Competitive Analysis
definition: Systematic evaluation of competing products, services, or companies to understand their strengths, weaknesses, features, and strategies. Competitive analysis identifies market opportunities, industry standards, and differentiation opportunities.

name: Component Adoption Rate
definition: Percentage of new designs using approved system components versus custom/ad-hoc implementations, measuring system effectiveness.

name: Component Deprecation
definition: Structured process for retiring outdated components while maintaining backward compatibility and smooth team transition.

name: Component Documentation
definition: Specs detailing component anatomy, states, variants, and usage guidelines.

name: Component Library
definition: Curated collection of reusable UI building blocks (buttons, cards, modals) with defined states, variants, and usage guidelines.

name: Component Promotion Workflow
definition: Design system approval publishing process.

name: Component Reuse Ratio
definition: Ratio of total components created to unique component types, where higher ratios indicate better reuse and system efficiency.

name: Component Specs
definition: Technical details for implementing specific UI components.

name: Component Variants
definition: Different states or versions of a component (primary/secondary button, large/small size) that maintain consistent behavior and visual language.

name: Concept Testing
definition: Evaluating an idea, feature, or product concept with users before significant development investment. Concept testing validates assumptions, gauges user interest, and identifies potential issues early when changes are still inexpensive.

name: Consistency Principle
definition: Same actions produce same results everywhere.

name: Container Queries
definition: Style components based on container size not viewport.

name: Content Analysis
definition: A systematic method for analyzing textual, visual, or audio content by categorizing and coding data into themes. Content analysis transforms qualitative information into quantifiable insights through structured examination.

name: Content Facet
definition: Attribute used to filter content collections.

name: Content Inventory
definition: Comprehensive list of existing content items and attributes.

name: Content Model
definition: Structured definition of content types and their properties.

name: Content Style Guide
definition: Standards for tone, voice, and writing conventions.

name: Contextual Inquiry
definition: A qualitative research method combining observation and interview in the user's actual work environment. Researchers observe users performing tasks in their natural context while asking questions to understand their motivations, challenges, and workflows.

name: Continuous Design Process
definition: Iterative shipping feedback cycles.

name: Continuous Discovery
definition: An ongoing research practice where product teams regularly interact with customers to inform decisions and validate assumptions throughout development. Continuous discovery embeds research into weekly routines rather than treating it as separate project phases.

name: Contrast Principle
definition: Color size differences create emphasis separation.

name: Contribution Docs
definition: Guidelines for teams extending or customizing the system.

name: Contribution Review Process
definition: Peer review merge standards.

name: Conversion Rate
definition: Percentage users completing desired action (purchase signup).

name: Core Web Vitals
definition: Google metrics measuring loading interactivity visual stability.

name: Cost of Delay
definition: A prioritization approach that quantifies the economic impact of time by calculating the value lost when a decision or initiative is delayed. Cost of Delay helps teams make urgent vs important trade-offs based on financial impact.

name: Crazy 8s Timed Sketch
definition: Fold paper into 8 sections sketch one idea per minute.

name: Critical CSS Extraction
definition: Extract above-fold styles for immediate rendering.

name: Cross-Browser Testing
definition: Functionality consistency across Chrome Firefox Safari Edge.

name: Cross-chart Filter
definition: Clicking one chart filters all connected charts simultaneously.

name: Cross-Device Testing
definition: iPhone Android tablet desktop behavior consistency.

name: Cross-Functional Workshop
definition: Mixed-discipline collaborative sessions.

name: CSS Clamp Function
definition: Dynamic value between min max based on viewport.

name: CSS Custom Properties
definition: Dynamic CSS variables for theming consistency.

name: CSS Feature Queries
definition: Conditional CSS based on browser feature support.

name: CSS Scroll Snap
definition: Snaps scroll container to specific points.

name: CSS Subgrid
definition: Child grid inherits parent grid tracks.

name: Customer Lifetime Value (LTV)
definition: Predicted net profit from entire customer relationship.

name: DACI Decision Roles
definition: Driver Approver Contributor Informed responsibilities.

name: Daily Active Users (DAU)
definition: Unique users using product per calendar day.

name: Daily Design Standup
definition: 15min team synchronization ritual.

name: Dark Mode Color Mapping
definition: A methodology for systematically adapting a light mode color palette to dark mode. Mapping defines how each color transforms: backgrounds invert from light to dark, text flips from dark to light, and accent colors adjust saturation and lightness to maintain visibility and reduce eye strain.

name: Dark Mode Guide
definition: Specifications for implementing theme variations.

name: Data Heat Grid
definition: Color intensity matrix shows value density across two categorical axes.

name: Data Point Drilldown
definition: Clicking aggregate data reveals component-level detail.

name: Data Visualization Color Scales
definition: A methodology for selecting appropriate color scales based on data type. Sequential scales (light to dark) show ordered data, diverging scales (two hues from a neutral center) show deviation from a midpoint, and categorical scales (distinct hues) differentiate unrelated categories.

name: Dead Click Analysis
definition: Clicks non-functional decorative elements.

name: Decorative Chart Elements
definition: Non-data ink elements distract from data message and reduce clarity.

name: Deep Linking Scheme
definition: URL schemes opening specific app screens.

name: Default State
definition: Normal resting appearance of interactive element before any user interaction.

name: Definition of Done
definition: Shared quality criteria story completion.

name: Design Brief Template
definition: Project scope objectives constraints success criteria.

name: Design Career Ladder
definition: Progression framework skill levels responsibilities.

name: Design Consistency Score
definition: Uniformity measurement across product surfaces.

name: Design Critique Session
definition: Structured peer feedback on in-progress design work.

name: Design Debt Score
definition: Quantitative measure of divergence from design system standards, calculated from component usage, token adherence, and consistency violations.

name: Design Decision Log
definition: Records explaining rationale behind key design choices.

name: Design Documentation
definition: Artifacts recording design processes, decisions, and deliverables for team alignment and consistency.

name: Design Governance
definition: The framework of processes, policies, and decision-making structures that guide design work and ensure consistency across an organization. Design governance defines who makes decisions, how standards are maintained, and how design quality is upheld.

name: Design Guild Meetings
definition: Cross-team community of practice sharing.

name: Design Handoff
definition: Package transferring designs to developers with specs, assets, and code snippets.

name: Design Office Hours
definition: Scheduled help troubleshooting availability.

name: Design Operations
definition: The orchestration of people, processes, and tools to enable design teams to create value more effectively. Also called DesignOps, it focuses on operational efficiency, workflow optimization, and removing blockers for designers.

name: Design Principles Definition
definition: Establishing clear, actionable guidelines that express the values and priorities guiding design decisions for a product or team. Design principles help teams make consistent choices and resolve conflicts during the design process.

name: Design Specification
definition: Detailed blueprint covering layouts, interactions, and responsive behaviors.

name: Design Sprint Process
definition: 5-day collaborative problem solving prototype testing.

name: Design System
definition: A centralized repository of reusable components, patterns, and guidelines that ensures visual and functional consistency across products and teams.

name: Design System Audit
definition: A systematic review of a design system and its implementation across products to identify inconsistencies, unused components, and improvement opportunities. Design system audits assess health and alignment between system and products.

name: Design System Contribution Rate
definition: Percentage of design system updates contributed by product designers versus dedicated system team, indicating healthy adoption.

name: Design System Maintenance
definition: The ongoing process of updating, improving, and supporting a design system to keep it relevant, usable, and aligned with product needs. Maintenance includes component updates, documentation improvements, version management, user support, and governance activities.

name: Design Systems First
definition: Build reusable components before custom work.

name: Design Token Migration
definition: Systematic process of updating token references across design files, codebases, and documentation during system evolution.

name: Design Token Semantics
definition: Meaningful names describing design intent not values.

name: Design Token Synchronization Pipeline
definition: Design-code token consistency automation.

name: Design Token Usage Coverage
definition: Percentage of UI elements referencing design tokens versus hardcoded values, indicating system maturity and maintainability.

name: Design Tokens
definition: Primitive values (colors, sizes, spacing) stored as variables to maintain consistency across design tools, code, and platforms.

name: Developer Satisfaction (DSAT)
definition: Survey-based metric measuring developer experience with design system quality, documentation, and implementation efficiency.

name: Diary Studies
definition: A longitudinal research method where participants self-report their experiences, behaviors, and activities over an extended period. Diary studies capture context and patterns that emerge over time in users' natural environments.

name: Disabled State
definition: Visual indication of unavailable interaction (grayed out, reduced opacity).

name: Discovery Sprint
definition: Week-long intensive problem validation research.

name: Documentation Audit
definition: Review assessing completeness and quality of design documentation.

name: Documentation Engagement
definition: Time spent views on system documentation.

name: Dogfood Testing
definition: Internal team uses own product before external launch.

name: Dot Voting Prioritization
definition: Team members allocate limited votes to prioritize ideas.

name: Double Diamond Process
definition: Discover Define Develop Deliver divergent convergent design phases.

name: Dropdown Menu
definition: Menu expanding downward from trigger showing related options.

name: Dynamic Date Range
definition: Slider controls instantly update all charts by selected time period.

name: Dynamic Type Scaling
definition: Text resizes with system accessibility settings.

name: Elevator Pitch Framework
definition: 30-second compelling value proposition.

name: Empathy Mapping
definition: A collaborative visualization tool that captures what users say, think, feel, and do to build shared understanding of user needs and behaviors. Empathy maps synthesize research observations into a simple, digestible format organized into four quadrants.

name: Empty State Design
definition: Meaningful content guidance when no data exists.

name: EN 301 549
definition: EU harmonized ICT accessibility standard incorporating WCAG 2.1 AA + mobile/hardware.

name: Error Prevention
definition: Design eliminates common user mistakes.

name: Error Rate Testing
definition: Frequency severity of user mistakes during tasks.

name: Error Recovery Path
definition: Easy undo back clear fix mechanisms.

name: Ethnographic Research
definition: Immersive study natural environment context.

name: European Accessibility Act (EAA)
definition: EU law mandating accessibility for digital products/services (effective June 2025).

name: Executive Briefing Deck
definition: Concise 5-8 slide leadership communication.

name: Executive Summary Chart
definition: Single chart conveys business situation instantly to leadership.

name: Exit Page Analysis
definition: Where users abandon before completing goals.

name: F-Pattern
definition: Content-heavy scan (top horizontal → left vertical → horizontals) for maximum visibility.

name: Faceted Navigation
definition: Multi-attribute filtering of content results.

name: Fake Door Test
definition: A validation technique that measures interest in a feature by adding an entry point for it in the interface before building it. Also called Smoke Test, fake door tests use click-through rates to assess demand and prevent wasted effort on unwanted features.

name: Feature Adoption Rate
definition: Percentage users using specific new feature.

name: Feedback Loops
definition: Systematic mechanisms for collecting, analyzing, and acting on information to drive continuous improvement. Feedback loops create cycles where outputs inform future inputs, enabling teams to learn and adapt iteratively.

name: Feedback Principle
definition: System confirms actions with immediate visible response.

name: Field Studies
definition: Research conducted in the user's natural environment by observing behavior and interactions in real-world contexts. Also called ethnographic research, field studies reveal how users actually behave rather than how they say they behave.

name: Figma Library
definition: Shared Figma file containing master components, styles, and assets synchronized across design team files for consistency.

name: Filter Panel
definition: Collapsible panel containing facet controls.

name: First-Click Testing
definition: Where users click first reveals IA effectiveness.

name: Fitts's Law
definition: Time to reach target inversely proportional to size, directly proportional to distance.

name: Five-Second Testing
definition: Brief exposure tests instant comprehension memory.

name: Flexbox Container
definition: One-dimensional layout for aligning distributing items.

name: Floating Action Button
definition: Prominent circular button for primary app action.

name: Focal Point
definition: Single dominant element capturing initial attention using multiple techniques.

name: Focus Groups
definition: A moderated group discussion with 6-10 participants to explore attitudes, perceptions, and opinions about a product, service, or concept. Focus groups gather diverse perspectives through facilitated conversation and group dynamics.

name: Focus Indicator
definition: Visible outline showing current keyboard focus location.

name: Focus Management
definition: Logical predictable keyboard focus order.

name: Focus Order
definition: Logical tab sequence matching visual reading order.

name: Focus State
definition: Keyboard navigation highlight for accessibility and screen readers.

name: Font Ascender
definition: Part of lowercase letters that extends above the x-height line (e.g., 'h', 'k', 'l', 'b', 'd'). Ascenders contribute to letter differentiation and rhythm in text blocks.

name: Font Descender
definition: Part of lowercase letters that extends below the baseline (e.g., 'g', 'j', 'p', 'q', 'y'). Descenders require adequate vertical space and affect line height calculations in UI design.

name: Font Display Swap
definition: Show fallback font immediately while custom loads.

name: Font Hierarchy
definition: Use of size, weight, color, and style to denote content importance and guide user focus. Font hierarchy creates visual structure that helps users scan and understand content priority.

name: Font Kerning
definition: Adjustment of space between individual letter pairs to improve visual balance and readability. Kerning compensates for the irregular shapes of letters, making text appear more cohesive.

name: Font Leading
definition: Vertical space between lines of text (line height). Named after the lead strips used in traditional typography, leading directly impacts readability and visual rhythm in text blocks.

name: Font Tracking
definition: Uniform adjustment of space between all letters in a word or line. Unlike kerning, tracking applies the same spacing value across an entire text block for consistent letter density.

name: Font Weight
definition: Thickness of characters in a font (e.g., Light, Regular, Bold, Black). Font weight creates visual emphasis, hierarchy, and contrast while maintaining a consistent typeface family.

name: Font X-Height
definition: Height of lowercase letters (excluding ascenders and descenders) in a font. X-height significantly influences perceived font size and legibility at small sizes, even when point size remains constant.

name: Footer Navigation
definition: Bottom-of-page links for secondary navigation, legal, and utility content.

name: Frequency Histogram
definition: Adjacent bars show distribution frequency of continuous numeric data.

name: Funnel Drop-off Analysis
definition: Drop-off rates at each conversion step.

name: Gamestorming
definition: A set of facilitation techniques that use game mechanics and playful activities to enhance ideation, problem-solving, and collaboration. Gamestorming structures creative sessions with clear rules, goals, and time constraints to increase engagement and output.

name: Gestalt Closure
definition: Incomplete shapes recognized as whole when context suggests completion.

name: Gestalt Common Fate
definition: Elements moving same direction perceived as belonging together.

name: Gestalt Common Region
definition: Elements within same bounded area automatically grouped together.

name: Gestalt Connectedness
definition: Connected elements (lines/shapes) perceived as single continuous unit.

name: Gestalt Continuity
definition: Eye follows lines/shapes in smooth, continuous paths rather than abrupt changes.

name: Gestalt Enclosure
definition: Containers/borders/backgrounds defining content chunks and hierarchy levels.

name: Gestalt Figure-Ground
definition: Distinguishing main subject (figure) from background (ground) through contrast.

name: Gestalt Proximity
definition: Close elements perceived as grouped; spacing defines relationships and creates visual chunks.

name: Gestalt Prägnanz
definition: Brain simplifies complex forms to simplest, most stable interpretation.

name: Gestalt Similarity
definition: Similar-looking elements grouped visually regardless of position through shared style/properties.

name: Gestalt Symmetry
definition: Symmetrical elements create balance, order, and visual stability.

name: Gesture
definition: Multi-touch input patterns (pinch, swipe, long-press, double-tap).

name: Glyph
definition: Individual character or symbol in a font, including letters, numbers, punctuation, and special symbols. Each glyph is a unique visual unit designed to work within a typeface system.

name: Golden Ratio
definition: 1:1.618 proportion creates natural visual harmony.

name: Grid Alignment
definition: Grid positioning creating visual flow, rhythm, and consistent relationships.

name: Guerrilla Testing
definition: Quick informal tests recruiting anyone available nearby.

name: Hamburger Menu
definition: Three-line icon expanding to reveal navigation drawer/menu (≡).

name: Haptic Feedback Types
definition: Distinct vibration patterns for different interactions.

name: Heatmap Analysis
definition: Visual representation of user click scroll attention patterns.

name: Heuristic Evaluation
definition: An expert review method where evaluators examine an interface against established usability principles (heuristics) to identify usability problems. Heuristic evaluation is quick, inexpensive, and effective for finding issues without involving users.

name: Hick's Law
definition: Decision time increases logarithmically with number of choices.

name: Hiring Rubric
definition: Structured evaluation criteria scoring system.

name: Hover State
definition: Visual change on mouse-over indicating interactivity and suggesting further action.

name: How Might We
definition: A question format that reframes problems as opportunities for ideation by using "How might we..." to open possibilities. HMW questions turn insights and challenges into actionable springboards for generating solutions.

name: Hub-and-Spoke Structure
definition: Central hub page linking to related content spokes.

name: Hundred Ideas Exercise
definition: Generate 100 ideas rapidly to push past obvious solutions.

name: Icon Baseline Alignment
definition: Icons aligned to text baseline for visual rhythm and consistency, ensuring proper vertical alignment with accompanying text.

name: Icon Family
definition: Icons sharing visual DNA across multiple weights, sizes, and styles (e.g., light, regular, bold) maintaining recognition and consistency.

name: Icon Grid
definition: Invisible structure (typically 24x24 or 32x32px) ensuring proportional consistency and alignment across all icons in a set.

name: Icon Library
definition: Curated collection of icons following consistent design system rules, style, weight, and grid specifications for organizational reuse.

name: Icon Scale
definition: Relative sizing system for icons across UI contexts (16px, 24px, 32px, etc.). Icon scale ensures proportional sizing and maintains visual consistency.

name: Icon Set
definition: Complete group of icons sharing identical style, weight, grid, and visual characteristics for cohesive interface communication.

name: Icon Style
definition: Consistent visual language applied to all icons (flat, skeuomorphic, outline, duotone, glyph). Icon style establishes design system coherence and aids user recognition across interface.

name: Icon Weight
definition: Thickness of strokes or boldness of filled shapes in icons. Icon weight creates visual hierarchy and differentiates icon importance within interface.

name: Ideation Workshop
definition: Structured creative problem solving session.

name: Infinite Scroll Pagination
definition: Content loads continuously without page refresh.

name: Information Architecture
definition: Organization and labeling of content so users can find and understand what they need.

name: Information Hierarchy
definition: Levels of content importance and relationships.

name: Interaction
definition: User input triggering system response (click, tap, hover, drag, swipe).

name: Interaction Cost
definition: Cognitive physical effort required per action.

name: Interaction Feedback
definition: System response confirming user action was received (animation, color change, sound).

name: iOS Human Interface
definition: Apple design guidelines conventions.

name: ISO 9241-171
definition: Ergonomics guidance on software accessibility and human-system interaction.

name: Jobs-to-be-Done
definition: User hires products for progress in life.

name: Journey Mapping
definition: A visualization of the process a user goes through to accomplish a goal, showing their actions, thoughts, emotions, and pain points across touchpoints over time. Journey maps synthesize research data to create a shared understanding of user experience and identify improvement opportunities.

name: Kano Model
definition: A prioritization framework that categorizes features based on their relationship to customer satisfaction. The Kano Model classifies features as Basic Needs, Performance Needs, or Delighters to help teams understand which features create the most value.

name: Keyboard Navigation
definition: Tab order and key actions enabling non-mouse interface control.

name: Keyboard Trap Detection
definition: Focus becomes stuck unable to tab forward/back.

name: KPI Performance Tracker
definition: Charts designed specifically for business goal metrics and thresholds.

name: Lab Usability Testing
definition: Controlled environment with eye-tracking specialized equipment.

name: Labeling System
definition: Rules for naming navigation items, categories, and content.

name: Landing Page Test
definition: A lean validation method that uses a simple web page to gauge market interest in a product or feature before building it. Landing page tests measure conversion rates to assess demand and collect leads from interested users.

name: Lazy Image Loading
definition: Images load only when scrolled into viewport.

name: Lean Canvas
definition: One-page business model visualization.

name: Lean UX Hypothesis
definition: We believe this will result in outcome we'll know success.

name: Learnability
definition: How quickly new users understand interface.

name: Legend Color Picker
definition: Interactive legend toggles series visibility and shows values.

name: Ligature
definition: Special glyph that combines two or more characters into a single unified form for improved visual flow and appearance (e.g., 'fi', 'fl', 'ffi'). Ligatures enhance readability and aesthetics in typography.

name: Line Graph
definition: Connected points show trends and changes over continuous time periods.

name: Line Length
definition: Number of characters per line of text. Optimal line length is 45-75 characters (or 8-12 words), balancing readability with scanning ease. Line length significantly impacts reading speed and comprehension.

name: Linear Flow
definition: Step-by-step sequence where each step has a single next action.

name: Loading State
definition: Temporary state during processing or data fetching.

name: Logical Properties
definition: Direction-agnostic CSS (inline-start vs left).

name: Long Press Context Menu
definition: Prolonged tap reveals additional options.

name: Lotus Blossom Diagram
definition: Central idea expands into 8 themes each with 8 sub-ideas.

name: Magic Number
definition: Product growth efficiency coefficient expansion.

name: Material Design Motion
definition: Google Android animation system.

name: Mega Menu
definition: Large dropdown with categorized sub-navigation and thumbnails.

name: Mental Model Mapping
definition: Document how users conceptualize system structure.

name: Micro Trendline
definition: Tiny inline line chart showing trend next to summary metric.

name: Micro-interaction
definition: Small, purposeful animations enhancing feedback and delight.

name: Miller's Law
definition: Average person holds 7±2 items in working memory.

name: Mind Mapping
definition: A visual thinking technique that organizes information hierarchically around a central concept, with related ideas branching outward. Mind mapping helps explore connections between ideas and structure thinking during ideation and problem-solving.

name: Minimal Data Noise
definition: Removing all non-essential visual elements maximizes data clarity.

name: Monadic Testing
definition: A research approach where each participant evaluates only one design or concept in isolation, without comparison to alternatives. Monadic testing provides unbiased feedback on each option's absolute merits without comparative context influencing responses.

name: MoSCoW Method
definition: A prioritization framework that categorizes requirements or features into four groups: Must have, Should have, Could have, and Won't have. MoSCoW helps teams agree on priorities and manage scope by making trade-offs explicit.

name: Multiple Chart Grid
definition: Grid of identical charts enables small multiple comparisons.

name: Multivariate Testing
definition: A quantitative testing method that evaluates multiple variables simultaneously to determine which combination of changes produces the best outcome. Multivariate testing tests all possible combinations of variables to find optimal designs.

name: Native Swipe Gestures
definition: Left/right swipes trigger list item actions.

name: Navigation Drawer
definition: Side panel sliding in from edge revealing additional navigation options.

name: Navigation Model
definition: Structure defining how users move between sections and screens.

name: Net Promoter Score (NPS)
definition: Single question measuring customer loyalty recommendation.

name: North Star Metric
definition: Single metric measuring core product value delivery.

name: Offline-First Architecture
definition: App works without internet designed first.

name: OKR Alignment Meeting
definition: Cross-team objective synchronization discussion.

name: OKR Framework
definition: Objectives (inspirational) Key Results (measurable).

name: Onboarding Process
definition: New hire first 90 days structured experience.

name: One-on-One Meeting
definition: Regular manager-direct report sync cadence.

name: Opportunity Interviews
definition: Customer conversations uncover unmet needs.

name: Opportunity Scoring
definition: A prioritization method that identifies opportunities by measuring the gap between how important a need is and how satisfied users currently are. The largest gaps represent the biggest opportunities for improvement.

name: Opportunity Solution Tree
definition: Visual map connecting outcomes to opportunities to solutions.

name: Override Detection Rate
definition: Percentage components with local style overrides.

name: Page Load Time
definition: Time request to interactive ready.

name: Pagination
definition: Controls for navigating through multiple pages of content.

name: Pair Design Sessions
definition: Two designers collaborative problem solving.

name: Pareto Principle
definition: 80% results come from 20% causes (80/20 rule).

name: Participatory Design
definition: Users co-create solutions collaborative workshops.

name: Pattern Library
definition: Catalog of reusable interaction and layout patterns with implementation examples.

name: Peak-End Rule
definition: Users judge experiences by peak moments and endings.

name: Perceptually Uniform Color Spaces
definition: Color spaces (LAB, LCH, OKLAB, OKLCH) designed so that equal numerical changes produce equal perceived visual changes. Unlike RGB or HSL, these spaces ensure that a 10-unit lightness change looks the same whether moving from light to mid or mid to dark tones.

name: Performance Budget
definition: Maximum acceptable thresholds for load time resources.

name: Performance Load Testing
definition: Speed interactions under network server stress.

name: Performance Review Cycle
definition: Structured evaluation feedback process.

name: Persona Development
definition: Creating fictional yet realistic representations of key user segments based on research data. Personas include demographics, behaviors, goals, motivations, and pain points to help teams empathize with and design for specific user types.

name: Pie Slice Chart
definition: Circular sectors show part-to-whole relationships and proportions.

name: Pinch to Zoom
definition: Two-finger spread/shrink controls magnification.

name: Polyfill Implementation
definition: JavaScript shims providing modern APIs to older browsers.

name: Power User Percentage
definition: Percentage users disproportionate value creation.

name: Pre-mortem Analysis
definition: Imagine project failed predict prevent risks.

name: Preference Testing
definition: Users choose preferred design from multiple options.

name: Preload Key Resources
definition: Fetch critical assets early in page load process.

name: Presentation Canvas
definition: Single page story structure key messages visuals.

name: Primary Navigation
definition: Main navigation presenting highest-level site sections and most important destinations.

name: Problem Framing
definition: The process of clearly defining and articulating a problem before seeking solutions. Problem framing shapes how teams understand challenges and influences the range of solutions they consider.

name: Problem Restatement
definition: Reframe problem multiple ways to unlock new solution angles.

name: Product Analytics
definition: The practice of collecting and analyzing quantitative data about how users interact with a product. Product analytics tools track behavior, usage patterns, funnels, and metrics to inform design and product decisions.

name: Product Roadmap
definition: Timeline prioritized feature delivery plan.

name: Progressive Disclosure
definition: Gradually revealing information based on user interaction and need.

name: Progressive Enhancement
definition: Core functionality first, enhancements layered.

name: Progressive Web App
definition: Website with native app features (install offline).

name: Prototype Guide
definition: Documentation of interactive prototype states, transitions, and behaviors.

name: Prototype Testing
definition: Evaluating an interactive representation of a design with users to validate functionality, flow, and usability before full development. Prototype testing uses clickable mockups or working prototypes to simulate the final experience.

name: Pull-to-Refresh
definition: Downward swipe gesture reloads content list.

name: RACI Matrix
definition: Responsible Accountable Consulted Informed assignments.

name: Radius Tokens
definition: Variables defining consistent border radius values for components to create unified visual style across the interface.

name: Rage Click Detection
definition: Frustrated repeated clicking non-functional areas.

name: Random Word Association
definition: Use unrelated words to spark unexpected creative connections.

name: Real-time Metrics Board
definition: Live-updating charts display streaming operational data continuously.

name: Reduced Motion
definition: Respect user's 'prefers-reduced-motion' OS setting.

name: Reference Grid Overlay
definition: Light background lines aid precise value reading and alignment.

name: Remote Usability Testing
definition: Online testing across geographic locations time zones.

name: Research Screener
definition: Pre-study survey qualifying research participants.

name: Responsive Guidelines
definition: Breakpoint-specific layout and behavior documentation.

name: Responsive Typography
definition: Scaling text proportionally using relative units (em, rem, %) across different screen sizes and devices. Responsive typography ensures readability and maintains visual hierarchy from mobile to desktop.

name: Retention Rate
definition: Percentage users returning after first use (D1 D7 D30).

name: Retrospectives
definition: A structured team reflection practice where members review what went well, what didn't, and what to improve for future work. Retrospectives create space for honest discussion and continuous team improvement.

name: Reverse Brainstorming
definition: Solve opposite problem then invert for actual solutions.

name: RICE Framework
definition: A prioritization framework that scores ideas based on four factors: Reach (number of users affected), Impact (effect on individual users), Confidence (certainty of estimates), and Effort (time required). RICE was developed by Intercom's product team to make objective, data-driven prioritization decisions.

name: Roadmap Alignment Workshop
definition: Stakeholder prioritization consensus building.

name: Rose Thorn Bud Canvas
definition: Categorize feedback as positives, negatives, and opportunities.

name: Round Robin Ideation
definition: Sequential idea building where each person adds to previous.

name: Rule of 40
definition: Growth + profit margin minimum 40% combined.

name: Rule of Thirds
definition: Canvas thirds create balanced focal points.

name: Safe Area Insets
definition: Screen areas avoiding notches status gesture bars.

name: Sans-Serif Fonts
definition: Clean typefaces without decorative strokes (serifs) at letter ends (e.g., Helvetica, Inter, Roboto). Sans-serifs are the modern standard for UI design, offering clarity and legibility on screens.

name: Satisfaction Metrics
definition: Post-task ratings CSAT SUS SEQ.

name: SCAMPER
definition: A structured creativity framework using seven prompts to generate new ideas by modifying existing products or concepts: Substitute, Combine, Adapt, Modify, Put to another use, Eliminate, and Reverse. SCAMPER provides systematic questions to spark creative thinking.

name: Screen Reader
definition: Software reading content aloud for visually impaired users (VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS).

name: Screen Reader Testing
definition: Manual testing with NVDA VoiceOver TalkBack.

name: Scroll Depth Tracking
definition: Percentage users reaching content sections.

name: Search Schema
definition: Rules defining searchable content, indexing, and ranking.

name: Secondary Navigation
definition: Supporting navigation for sub-sections, categories, or context-specific links.

name: Semantic HTML
definition: Meaningful markup (headings, lists, landmarks) aiding assistive technology.

name: Semantic Landmarks
definition: ARIA roles identify page regions.

name: SEO-First Content Markup
definition: Semantic HTML optimized for search engine crawling.

name: Serial Position Effect
definition: Better recall of first and last items in sequence.

name: Serif Fonts
definition: Typefaces with small decorative strokes (serifs) extending from the ends of letters. Serifs add formality and tradition to typography and are often used for editorial content or formal applications.

name: Session Duration
definition: Average time spent per user session.

name: Shake to Undo
definition: Device shake cancels recent destructive action.

name: Sitemap
definition: Diagram showing all pages/screens and their relationships.

name: Six Thinking Hats
definition: De Bono's method using six perspectives for structured thinking.

name: Skeleton Loading State
definition: Low-fidelity preview content structure while loading.

name: Smoke Testing
definition: Basic functionality verification immediately post-deploy.

name: Sort Order
definition: Default and alternate ordering rules for content lists.

name: Spacing Scale
definition: Standardized set of spacing values (4px, 8px, 16px multiples) used consistently for margins, padding, and gaps throughout the interface.

name: Speedboat Canvas
definition: Visual metaphor identifying what slows team or product progress.

name: Sprint Planning Meeting
definition: 2hr commitment planning session.

name: Sprint Review Demo
definition: Stakeholder showcase working software.

name: Stacked Area Graph
definition: Filled areas show contribution of parts to cumulative total over time.

name: Stakeholder Interviews
definition: Structured conversations with internal stakeholders to understand business goals, constraints, requirements, and perspectives. Stakeholder interviews align design work with organizational objectives and surface potential conflicts early.

name: Stakeholder Map
definition: Influence interest power prioritization matrix.

name: Starfish Retrospective
definition: Five-category retrospective: keep, more, less, stop, start.

name: Status Bar Behavior
definition: Top bar shows/hides based on scroll/content needs.

name: Stepper
definition: Linear multi-step process navigation (Step 1 of 4).

name: Stickiness Ratio
definition: DAU/MAU ratio measures daily engagement.

name: Sticky Navigation Bar
definition: Navigation stays fixed during scroll.

name: Storytelling Arc
definition: Problem solution impact narrative structure.

name: Style Guide
definition: Comprehensive reference document detailing visual, interaction, and content guidelines for consistent design application.

name: Surveys
definition: A structured research method using questionnaires to collect quantitative and qualitative data from a large number of respondents. Surveys measure attitudes, behaviors, satisfaction, and demographics across representative samples.

name: SUS Questionnaire
definition: 10-question standardized usability scale benchmark.

name: SUS Score
definition: 10-question standardized usability benchmark 0-100.

name: Tab Bar
definition: Horizontal tabs switching between related content views (Content 1 | Content 2).

name: Tagging System
definition: Descriptive keywords assigned to content for findability.

name: Task Completion Testing
definition: Success rates time-on-task metrics measurement.

name: Task Flow
definition: Simplified flow focusing on a single user goal and decision points.

name: Task Success Rate
definition: Percentage completing tasks without assistance.

name: Taxonomy
definition: Controlled vocabulary and classification system for content.

name: Team OKR Cascading
definition: Company → team → individual objective connection.

name: Test Scenario Development
definition: Realistic user goal-based tasks for testing.

name: Text Alignment
definition: Positioning of text relative to margins or guides: left-aligned, center-aligned, right-aligned, or justified. Text alignment affects readability, visual flow, and information hierarchy in UI layouts.

name: Text Alternative
definition: Non-visual descriptions for images/media (alt text, captions).

name: Text Resizing
definition: Content readable up to 200% zoom without loss of functionality.

name: Thematic Analysis
definition: A qualitative research method for identifying, analyzing, and reporting patterns (themes) within data. Thematic analysis systematically organizes and describes research findings by coding data and grouping codes into meaningful themes.

name: Think-Aloud Protocol
definition: Users verbalize thoughts while completing tasks.

name: Time on Task
definition: Average completion time standard tasks.

name: Touch Target
definition: Minimum interactive area size for comfortable finger interaction.

name: Tree Testing
definition: A usability method that evaluates the findability and labeling of topics in a navigation structure by asking participants to locate items in a text-only hierarchy. Tree testing validates information architecture before visual design.

name: Type Scale
definition: A system of font sizes based on mathematical ratios (e.g., 1.125, 1.25, 1.618) for consistent sizing across UI elements. Type scale ensures visual hierarchy and coherence without arbitrary font size choices.

name: Typography Baseline
definition: Imaginary line upon which letters sit, serving as a reference for alignment. Baseline is fundamental for vertical rhythm and text alignment in UI layouts.

name: Typography Contrast
definition: Difference in weight, size, color, or style between typographic elements. Contrast creates visual interest, guides focus, and establishes hierarchy to improve scannability and user comprehension.

name: Typography Legibility
definition: Ease of distinguishing individual characters from one another. Legibility depends on font design, size, spacing, and contrast. High legibility is essential for accessible, user-friendly interfaces.

name: Typography Readability
definition: Ease of reading and comprehending blocks of text. Readability encompasses legibility, line length, line height, color contrast, and overall layout. It measures how comfortably users can consume content.

name: Typography Rhythm
definition: Consistent vertical flow and spacing created by leading, line height, and baseline grids. Rhythm creates visual harmony, improves scanability, and establishes visual continuity across typography.

name: UI Transition
definition: Smooth property change between states (color, position, opacity) with duration and easing.

name: Usability Testing
definition: A research method where representative users attempt realistic tasks with a product or prototype while observers watch, listen, and take notes. Usability testing reveals where users struggle, identifying design problems and opportunities for improvement.

name: Usage Guidelines
definition: Rules explaining when and how to apply specific design elements correctly.

name: User Flow
definition: Ordered sequence of steps a user takes to accomplish a task.

name: User Interviews
definition: One-on-one conversations with users to understand their needs, behaviors, motivations, and pain points. User interviews collect qualitative data through open-ended questions and are typically conducted in the early discovery stages or to complement other research methods.

name: UX Style Guide
definition: Standards for user flows, microcopy, and interaction consistency.

name: Value Proposition Testing
definition: Validate product-market assumptions experiments.

name: Value vs Effort Matrix
definition: A 2x2 prioritization framework plotting initiatives based on their expected value to users or business and the effort required to implement. Also called Impact-Effort Matrix, it helps identify quick wins and avoid low-value, high-effort work.

name: Variable Fonts
definition: Single font file multiple weights widths styles.

name: Version Documentation
definition: Changelog and migration guides for design system updates.

name: View Transitions API
definition: Declarative page transition animations.

name: Viewport Meta Tag
definition: HTML tag controlling mobile zoom scaling behavior.

name: Viral Coefficient
definition: Average new users per existing user referral.

name: Visual Hierarchy
definition: Size position color organize content by importance.

name: Visual Hierarchy Priority
definition: Size position color prioritize most important data elements.

name: Visual Language Guide
definition: Rules for icons, illustrations, and graphical element usage.

name: Visual Regression Failures
definition: Number of visual differences detected between design mockups and implemented components during automated testing.

name: Visual Repetition
definition: Consistent styling unifying interface and reinforcing visual relationships.

name: Von Restorff Effect
definition: Unique items remembered better than uniform ones.

name: Wayfinding
definition: Environmental cues helping users orient and navigate complex information spaces.

name: WCAG
definition: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines - W3C international standard (A, AA, AAA levels).

name: WCAG Success Criteria
definition: Measurable testable accessibility requirements.

name: Wear OS Complications
definition: Customizable glanceable data watch face.

name: Web Share API
definition: Native browser sharing interface.

name: Weighted Shortest Job First
definition: Cost of Delay ÷ Job Size = priority score.

name: White Space
definition: Strategic empty areas isolating focal points and creating content separation.

name: Wireframe Specification
definition: Annotated wireframes with functional and content requirements.

name: Wizard of Oz Testing
definition: A testing method where users interact with what appears to be a functioning system, but a human operator manually provides responses behind the scenes. Wizard of Oz testing validates concepts and interactions before building complex functionality.

name: Worst Idea Generation
definition: Deliberately generate bad ideas then reverse into solutions.

name: XY Scatter Plot
definition: Points on coordinate plane reveal correlations between two variables.

name: Z-Pattern
definition: Simple layout scan path (left→right→left→right) following natural eye movement.

name: Zeigarnik Effect
definition: Incomplete tasks remembered better than completed.
